channel.title: Freakonomics Radio
channel.description: In their books "Freakonomics" and "SuperFreakonomics," Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner explore "the hidden side of everything," with stories about cheating schoolteachers, self-dealing real-estate agents, and crack-selling mama’s boys. The Freakonomics Radio podcast, hosted by Dubner, carries on that tradition with weekly episodes. Prepare to be enlightened, engaged, perhaps enraged, and definitely surprised.
channel.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
channel.itunes:subtitle: The latest articles from Freakonomics Radio

item.title: Freakonomics Goes to College, Part 2
item.description: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?

item.title: The Season of Death
item.description: We know that summertime brings far too many fatal accidents. But you may be surprised if you dig into the numbers.

item.title: Star-Spangled Banter?
item.description: Once a week, the British Prime Minister goes before the House of Commons for a lightning round of hard questions. Should the U.S. give it a try?

item.title: Riding the Herd Mentality
item.description: How using peer pressure -- and good, old-fashioned shame -- can push people to do the right thing.

item.title: A Cheap Employee Is … a Cheap Employee
item.description: Paying workers as little as possible seems smart -- unless you can make more money by paying them more.

item.title: Wildfires, Cops, and Keggers

item.title: The Suicide Paradox
item.description: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.

item.title: Does College Still Matter? And Other Freaky Questions Answered ...
item.description: In our second round of FREAK-quently Asked Questions, Steve Levitt answers some queries from listeners and readers.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: In our second round of FREAK-quently Asked Questions, Steve Levitt answers some queries from listeners and readers.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: In our second round of FREAK-quently Asked Questions, Steve Levitt answers some queries from listeners and readers.

item.title: Smarter Kids at 10 Bucks a Pop
item.description: It won’t work for everyone, but there’s a cheap, quick, and simple way to lift some students’ grades.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: It won’t work for everyone, but there’s a cheap, quick, and simple way to lift some students’ grades.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: It won’t work for everyone, but there’s a cheap, quick, and simple way to lift some students’ grades.

item.title: Why Can’t We Predict Earthquakes?
item.description: We talk to a U.S. Geological Survey physicist about the science -- and folly -- of predicting earthquakes. There are lots of known knowns; and, fortunately, not too many unknown unknowns. But it's the known unknowns -- the timing of the next Big One -- that are the most dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: We talk to a U.S. Geological Survey physicist about the science -- and folly -- of predicting earthquakes. There are lots of known knowns; and, fortunately, not too many unknown unknowns. But it's the known unknowns -- the timing of the next Big One -- t
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: We talk to a U.S. Geological Survey physicist about the science -- and folly -- of predicting earthquakes. There are lots of known knowns; and, fortunately, not too many unknown unknowns. But it's the known unknowns -- the timing of the next Big One -- that are the most dangerous.

item.title: Death by Fire? Probably Not
item.description: Fire deaths in the U.S. have fallen 90 percent over the past 100 years, a great and greatly underappreciated gain. How did it happen -- and could we ever get to zero?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Fire deaths in the U.S. have fallen 90 percent over the past 100 years, a great and greatly underappreciated gain. How did it happen -- and could we ever get to zero?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: Fire deaths in the U.S. have fallen 90 percent over the past 100 years, a great and greatly underappreciated gain. How did it happen -- and could we ever get to zero?

item.title: The Health of Nations
item.description: For decades, GDP has been the yardstick for measuring living standards around the world. Martha Nussbaum would rather use something that actually works.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: For decades, GDP has been the yardstick for measuring living standards around the world. Martha Nussbaum would rather use something that actually works.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: For decades, GDP has been the yardstick for measuring living standards around the world. Martha Nussbaum would rather use something that actually works.

item.title: Is Twitter a Two-Way Street?
item.description: To get a lot of followers on Twitter, do you need to follow a lot of other Tweeps? And if not, why not?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: To get a lot of followers on Twitter, do you need to follow a lot of other Tweeps? And if not, why not?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: To get a lot of followers on Twitter, do you need to follow a lot of other Tweeps? And if not, why not?

item.title: The Power of Poop
item.description: Since the beginning of civilization, we’ve thought that human waste was worthless and dangerous. What if we were wrong?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Since the beginning of civilization, we’ve thought that human waste was worthless and dangerous. What if we were wrong?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner

item.title: Millionaires vs. Billionaires
item.description: Five things you don’t know about the NFL labor standoff
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Five things you don’t know about the NFL labor standoff
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: Five things you don’t know about the NFL labor standoff

item.title: Why Cities Rock
item.description: Could it be that cities are "our greatest invention" -- that, despite a reputation as black-soot-spewing engines of doom, they in fact make us richer, smarter, happier and (believe it!) greener?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Could it be that cities are "our greatest invention" -- that, despite a reputation as black-soot-spewing engines of doom, they in fact make us richer, smarter, happier and (believe it!) greener?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: Could it be that cities are "our greatest invention" -- that, despite a reputation as black-soot-spewing engines of doom, they in fact make us richer, smarter, happier and (believe it!) greener?

item.title: Bring on the Pain!
item.description: It's not about how much something hurts -- it's how you remember the pain. This week, lessons on pain from the New York City subway, the professional hockey rink, and a landmark study of colonoscopy patients. So have a listen; we promise, it won't hurt a bit.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner

item.title: Waiter, There’s a Physicist in My Soup! (Part 2)
item.description: What do a computer hacker, an Indiana farm boy, and Napoleon Bonaparte have in common? The past, present, and future of food science.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: What do a computer hacker, an Indiana farm boy, and Napoleon Bonaparte have in common? The past, present, and future of food science.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: What do a computer hacker, an Indiana farm boy, and Napoleon Bonaparte have in common? The past, present, and future of food science.

item.title: Waiter, There’s a Physicist in My Soup! (Part 1)
item.description: The "molecular gastronomy" movement -- which gets a bump in visibility next month with the publication of the mammoth cookbook "Modernist Cuisine" -- is all about bringing more science into the kitchen. In many ways, it's the opposite of the "slow food" movement. In this episode, you'll hear chieftains from the two camps square off: Alice Waters for the slow foodies and Nathan Myhrvold for the mad scientists. Bon appetit!
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner

In this episode, you'll hear chieftains from the two camps square off: Alice Waters for the slow foodies and Nathan Myhrvold for the mad scientists. Bon appetit!

item.title: Freakonomics FAQ, No. 1
item.description: Levitt and Dubner field questions from the public and hold forth on everything from dating strategies and rock-and-roll accordion music to whether different nations have different economic identities. Oh, and also: is it worthwhile to vote?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Levitt and Dubner field questions from the public and hold forth on everything from dating strategies and rock-and-roll accordion music to whether different nations have different economic identities. Oh, and also: is it worthwhile to vote?

item.title: Trashed
item.description: How economics -- and emotion -- have turned our garbage into such a mess
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner

item.title: Exit Interview: Schools Chancellor, NYC
item.description: Having already amassed an eventful resume -- the Clinton White House, the Department of Justice, and Bertelsmann -- Joel I. Klein spent the past eight years at chancellor of the biggest school system in the country. So what'd he learn?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Having already amassed an eventful resume -- the Clinton White House, the Department of Justice, and Bertelsmann -- Joel I. Klein spent the past eight years at chancellor of the biggest school system in the country. So what'd he learn?

item.title: You Say Repugnant, I Say … Let's Do It!
item.description: What happens when the most disturbing ideas are also the best?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: What happens when the most disturbing ideas are also the best?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: What happens when the most disturbing ideas are also the best?

item.title: Do More Expensive Wines Taste Better?
item.description: They should! It's a cardinal rule: more expensive items are supposed to be qualitatively better than their cheaper versions. But is that true for wine?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: They should! It's a cardinal rule: more expensive items are supposed to be qualitatively better than their cheaper versions. But is that true for wine?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: They should! It's a cardinal rule: more expensive items are supposed to be qualitatively better than their cheaper versions. But is that true for wine?

item.title: The "No-Lose Lottery," Part 2
item.description: It’s the banking tool that got millions of people around the world to stop wasting money on the lottery. So why won't state and federal officials in the U.S. give it a chance?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: It’s the banking tool that got millions of people around the world to stop wasting money on the lottery. So why won't state and federal officials in the U.S. give it a chance?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: It’s the banking tool that got millions of people around the world to stop wasting money on the lottery. So why won't state and federal officials in the U.S. give it a chance?

item.title: Is America Ready for a "No-Lose Lottery"?
item.description: For the most part, Americans don't like the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. We do, however, love to play the lottery. So what if you combined the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: For the most part, Americans don't like the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. We do, however, love to play the lottery. So what if you combined the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout?
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: For the most part, Americans don't like the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. We do, however, love to play the lottery. So what if you combined the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout?

item.title: How Much Does the President of the U.S. Really Matter?
item.description: The U.S. president is often called the "leader of free world." But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won't say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner

But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won't say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.

item.title: The NFL's Best Real Estate Isn't For Sale. Yet.
item.description: The NFL is very good at making money. So why on earth doesn't it sell ad space on the one piece of real estate that football fans can’t help but see: the players themselves? The explanation is trickier than you might think. It has to do with Peyton Manning, with Eli Manning, and with ... wait for it ... Tevye.

item.title: Reading, Rockets, and 'Rithmetic
item.description: Government and the private sector often feel far apart. One is filled with compliance-driven bureaucracy. The other, with market-fueled innovation. But something is changing in a multi-billion dollar corner of the Department of Education. It's an experiment, which takes cues from the likes of Google and millionaires who hope to go to the moon.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner

item.title: Who Stole All the Runs in Major League Baseball?
item.description: It was a pretty good baseball season -- especially if you're a fan of the Yankees, Rays, Twins, Rangers, Reds, Braves, Phillies, or Giants, all of whom made the playoffs. But the post-season just opened with a telling event, a no-hitter pitched by the Phillies' Roy Halladay, which shows what's been missing all season: runs.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: It was a pretty good baseball season -- especially if you're a fan of the Yankees, Rays, Twins, Rangers, Reds, Braves, Phillies, or Giants, all of whom made the playoffs. But the post-season just opened with a telling event, a no-hitter pitched by the Ph

But the post-season just opened with a telling event, a no-hitter pitched by the Phillies' Roy Halladay, which shows what's been missing all season: runs.

item.title: Two Book Authors and a Microphone
item.description: The next chapter in the adventures of Dubner and Levitt has begun. Listen to a preview of what's to come for the fall season of Freakonomics Radio.

item.title: Why the World Cup Is an Economist's Dream
item.description: Steve Levitt talks about why the center cannot hold in penalty kicks, why a running track hurts home-field advantage, and why the World Cup is an economist's dream.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Steve Levitt talks about why the center cannot hold in penalty kicks, why a running track hurts home-field advantage, and why the World Cup is an economist's dream.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: Steve Levitt talks about why the center cannot hold in penalty kicks, why a running track hurts home-field advantage, and why the World Cup is an economist's dream.

item.title: How Is a Bad Radio Station Like Our Public-School System?
item.description: In this episode of Freakonomics Radio, we explore a way to make 1.1 million schoolkids feel like they have 1.1 million teachers.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: In this episode of Freakonomics Radio, we explore a way to make 1.1 million schoolkids feel like they have 1.1 million teachers.
item.itunes:author: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:summary: In this episode of Freakonomics Radio, we explore a way to make 1.1 million schoolkids feel like they have 1.1 million teachers.

item.title: Faking It
item.description: Do you "fake it"? If so, you're hardly alone. In this episode, you'll hear how everyone from the President of the United States to a kosher-keeping bacon lover lives in a state of fallen grace. All the time. And gets by.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: Do you "fake it"? If so, you're hardly alone. In this episode, you'll hear how everyone from the President of the United States to a kosher-keeping bacon lover lives in a state of fallen grace. All the time. And gets by.

item.title: What Would the World Look Like if Economists Were in Charge?
item.description: In this episode we speculate what would happen if economists got to run the world. Hear from a high-end call girl; an Estonian who ran his country according to the gospel of Milton Friedman; and a guy who wants to start building new nations in the middle of the ocean.
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
item.itunes:subtitle: In this episode we speculate what would happen if economists got to run the world. Hear from a high-end call girl; an Estonian who ran his country according to the gospel of Milton Friedman; and a guy who wants to start building new nations in the middle

item.title: Is America's Obesity Epidemic For Real?
item.description: Americans keep putting on pounds. So is it time for a cheeseburger tax? Or would a chill pill be the best medicine? In this episode, we explore the underbelly of fat through the eyes of a 280-pound woman, a top White House doctor, and a couple of overweight academics.

item.title: The Dangers of Safety
item.description: What do NASCAR drivers, Glenn Beck and the hit men of the NFL have in common?
item.dc:creator: Stephen J. Dubner
